elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cap0005">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">(a) Section of an inorganic layer with 20-ring windows in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> viewed along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis. (b) Arrangement of the layers in the <ce:italic>bc</ce:italic> plane. The yellow and green polyhedra represent ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, respectively. The blue, black, and red circles indicate the N atoms, C atoms, and water molecules, respectively. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  (a) Section of an inorganic layer with 20-ring windows in 1 viewed along the c axis. (b) Arrangement of the layers in the bc plane. The yellow and green polyhedra represent ZnO4 and HPO3, respectively. The blue, black, and red circles indicate the N atoms, C atoms, and water molecules, respectively. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0010">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cap0010">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">(a) View of the neutral layer in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> formed by 4- and 8-membered rings. (b) Arrangement of the layers in the <ce:italic>ab</ce:italic> plane. The yellow and green polyhedra represent ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N and HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, respectively. The blue and black circles indicate the N and C atoms, respectively. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  (a) View of the neutral layer in 2 formed by 4- and 8-membered rings. (b) Arrangement of the layers in the ab plane. The yellow and green polyhedra represent ZnO3N and HPO3, respectively. The blue and black circles indicate the N and C atoms, respectively. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0015">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cap0015">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">Two different types of structural units in <ce:bold>3:</ce:bold> (a) a group formed by three ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and two HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> tetrahedra, and (b) a unit formed by one ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N and three HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> tetrahedra. (c) A section of the inorganic layer showing two types of 8-membered rings and one 4-membered ring. (d) Arrangement of the layers in the <ce:italic>ab</ce:italic> plane. The orange, yellow, and green polyhedra represent ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N, ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, and HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, respectively. The blue and black circles indicate the N and C atoms, respectively. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr3"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  Two different types of structural units in 3: (a) a group formed by three ZnO4 and two HPO3 tetrahedra, and (b) a unit formed by one ZnO3N and three HPO3 tetrahedra. (c) A section of the inorganic layer showing two types of 8-membered rings and one 4-membered ring. (d) Arrangement of the layers in the ab plane. The orange, yellow, and green polyhedra represent ZnO3N, ZnO4, and HPO3, respectively. The blue and black circles indicate the N and C atoms, respectively. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

<ce:section-title id="sect0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0030" view="all">Three-layered zinc phosphites containing single monoamine molecules with different roles have been synthesized using hydro(solvo)thermal methods and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis, and infrared spectroscopy. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, (C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, consists of 20-ring layer structures sandwiched by water molecules and protonated <ce:italic>tert</ce:italic>-octylamine molecules. The structure of Zn(C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)(HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>) (compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) is composed of 4.8<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> network structures, wherein the <ce:italic>tert</ce:italic>-octylamines are coordinated to the Zn atom as pendant groups. Compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, (C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)(HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>, was prepared in which the amine plays a dual role as both a ligand and a countercation. In addition, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is the first layered metal phosphite with large 20-ring windows. This group of substances represents the first example of the preparation of compounds in which the reactivity of incorporated single amine molecules is varied by adjusting the synthesis conditions.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Three-layered zinc phosphites containing single monoamine molecules with different roles have been synthesized using hydro(solvo)thermal methods and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis, and infrared spectroscopy. Compound 1, (C8H17NH3)4Zn3(HPO3)5⋅3H2O, consists of 20-ring layer structures sandwiched by water molecules and protonated tert-octylamine molecules. The structure of Zn(C8H17NH2)(HPO3) (compound 2) is composed of 4.82 network structures, wherein the tert-octylamines are coordinated to the Zn atom as pendant groups. Compound 3, (C8H17NH3)2Zn4(C8H17NH2)(HPO3)5, was prepared in which the amine plays a dual role as both a ligand and a countercation. In addition, compound 1 is the first layered metal phosphite with large 20-ring windows. This group of substances represents the first example of the preparation of compounds in which the reactivity of incorporated single amine molecules is varied by adjusting the synthesis conditions.

elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

The first layered metal phosphite with large 20-ring windows, (C8H17NH3)4Zn3(HPO3)5⋅3H2O (1), sandwiched by water molecules and protonated tert-octylamine molecules.     

Highlights

   ⋅ The first example of zinc phosphites contains amine molecules with template and ligand roles.   ⋅ The reactivity of single amine molecules is varied by adjusting the synthesis conditions.   ⋅ Compound 1 contains the largest pore opening of 20-rings in known layered metal phosphites.   ⋅ Compound 3 has dual roles of amine molecules in its structure.

elements.clean_text:
The first example of zinc phosphites contains amine molecules with template and ligand roles.

The reactivity of single amine molecules is varied by adjusting the synthesis conditions.

Compound 1 contains the largest pore opening of 20-rings in known layered metal phosphites.

Compound 3 has dual roles of amine molecules in its structure.

Introduction

Great effort has been devoted to the synthesis of metal phosphates in the presence of organic amines because of the interesting structural features and potential applications of the resulting compounds in intercalation, catalysis, and ion exchange applications . The amines usually play two different roles in the formation of metal phosphate structures: (1) as templates or space-filling counterions, which is the most common; and (2) as ligands that bind to the metal, as in [In5F3(PO4)4(H2O)2(en)3] . It is less common that amines take on both roles in one structure. Only two phosphates have been previously reported that exhibit this behavior: a zincophosphate with 1,3-diaminopropane molecules and a gallophosphate with 1,2-diaminocyclohexane molecules .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Recently, the pseudotetrahedral phosphite group HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> has been employed as a replacement building unit for the tetrahedral phosphate group. The HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> group gives rise to new classes of organic–inorganic hybrid compounds and crystalline materials with extra-large pores . In addition to the synthesis of these interesting compounds, one interesting research field involves the study of the influence of amines on the inorganic composition of these materials. A variety of organic amines display versatile structural features and play different roles in the formation of interesting structures, including roles as ligands and templates, depending on the synthesis conditions, which results in forming new materials with different chemical compositions and structural topologies.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Recently, the pseudotetrahedral phosphite group HPO3 2- has been employed as a replacement building unit for the tetrahedral phosphate group. The HPO3 2- group gives rise to new classes of organic-inorganic hybrid compounds and crystalline materials with extra-large pores . In addition to the synthesis of these interesting compounds, one interesting research field involves the study of the influence of amines on the inorganic composition of these materials. A variety of organic amines display versatile structural features and play different roles in the formation of interesting structures, including roles as ligands and templates, depending on the synthesis conditions, which results in forming new materials with different chemical compositions and structural topologies.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0035" view="all">Herein, we report the synthesis of three new layered zinc phosphites using hydro(solvo)thermal methods that contain the monoamine <ce:italic>tert</ce:italic>-octylamine (TOA), which perform different roles in each compound. This group of compounds represents the first example where a single monoamine molecule plays different roles in three zinc phosphites owing to changes in the reaction conditions. Compound (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), (C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, possesses a sheet structure with 20-membered rings sandwiched by water molecules and protonated (HTOA)<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> templates; compound (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), Zn(C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)(HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>), has an undulated layer structure with the neutral TOA ligands coordinated to the Zn as pendent groups; and compound (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), (C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)(HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>, contains TOA molecules that act as both neutral ligands and protonated templates in the structure.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Herein, we report the synthesis of three new layered zinc phosphites using hydro(solvo)thermal methods that contain the monoamine tert-octylamine (TOA), which perform different roles in each compound. This group of compounds represents the first example where a single monoamine molecule plays different roles in three zinc phosphites owing to changes in the reaction conditions. Compound (1), (C8H17NH3)4Zn3(HPO3)5⋅3H2O, possesses a sheet structure with 20-membered rings sandwiched by water molecules and protonated (HTOA)+ templates; compound (2), Zn(C8H17NH2)(HPO3), has an undulated layer structure with the neutral TOA ligands coordinated to the Zn as pendent groups; and compound (3), (C8H17NH3)2Zn4(C8H17NH2)(HPO3)5, contains TOA molecules that act as both neutral ligands and protonated templates in the structure.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0030">Experimental section</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sect0035">Synthesis and characterization</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">The hydro(solvo)thermal reactions were carried out in Teflon-lined stainless steel Parr acid digestion bombs at 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>d. Colorless block crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were obtained by heating a mixture of Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), HF(aq) (0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 48% solution), H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M solution), <ce:italic>tert</ce:italic>-octylamine (12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL), and ethylene glycol (4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL). Colorless tablet crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were prepared by heating a mixture of Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), HF(aq) (2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 48% solution), H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M solution), <ce:italic>tert</ce:italic>-octylamine (12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL). Colorless tablet crystals of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were synthesized by heating a mixture of Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), HF(aq) (2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 48% solution), H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M solution), <ce:italic>tert</ce:italic>-octylamine (12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (1.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL), and ethylene glycol (5.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL). The addition of ethylene glycol (1–2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) to the same reaction condition of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> led the formation of the mixture of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. Attempts to synthesize <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> without ethylene glycol were unsuccessful.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental section

Synthesis and characterization

The hydro(solvo)thermal reactions were carried out in Teflon-lined stainless steel Parr acid digestion bombs at 120°C for 3d. Colorless block crystals of 1 were obtained by heating a mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.5mmol), HF(aq) (0.5mmol, 48% solution), H3PO3 (7mmol, 8M solution), tert-octylamine (12mmol), H2O (1mL), and ethylene glycol (4mL). Colorless tablet crystals of 2 were prepared by heating a mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.5mmol), HF(aq) (2mmol, 48% solution), H3PO3 (3mmol, 8M solution), tert-octylamine (12mmol), and H2O (5mL). Colorless tablet crystals of 3 were synthesized by heating a mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.4mmol), HF(aq) (2mmol, 48% solution), H3PO3 (6mmol, 8M solution), tert-octylamine (12mmol), H2O (1.4mL), and ethylene glycol (5.6mL). The addition of ethylene glycol (1-2mL) to the same reaction condition of 2 led the formation of the mixture of 1 and 2. Attempts to synthesize 1 and 3 without ethylene glycol were unsuccessful.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0045" view="all">Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of the bulk products <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are in good agreement with the calculated patterns based on the results of single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses (). Energy-dispersive X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy of several colorless crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> confirmed the presence of Zn and P. Elemental analysis results for the bulk products are consistent with the formulas presented for the compounds. Anal. Found (calcd) for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>: C, 33.03% (32.92%); H, 7.99% (7.86%); N, 4.89% (4.80%). Anal. Found (calcd) for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>: C, 35.37% (35.16%); H, 7.49% (7.38%); N, 5.26% (5.13%). Anal. Found (calcd) for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>: C, 27.62% (27.56%); H, 6.29% (6.17%); N, 4.24% (4.02%).</ce:para>

Energy-dispersive X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy of several colorless crystals of 1, 2, and 3 confirmed the presence of Zn and P. Elemental analysis results for the bulk products are consistent with the formulas presented for the compounds. Anal. Found (calcd) for 1: C, 33.03% (32.92%); H, 7.99% (7.86%); N, 4.89% (4.80%). Anal. Found (calcd) for 2: C, 35.37% (35.16%); H, 7.49% (7.38%); N, 5.26% (5.13%). Anal. Found (calcd) for 3: C, 27.62% (27.56%); H, 6.29% (6.17%); N, 4.24% (4.02%).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) using a Perkin Elmer TGA7 thermal analyzer was performed on powder samples of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> in O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> over a temperature range of 40–900<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C at a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (). In the case of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, a first weight loss of 4.56% occurred in the range of 50–137<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, which corresponds to the loss of the free water molecules (calcd. 4.63%). The X-ray powder patterns of the final decomposition products from the TG analyses showed the presence of Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf> (JCPDS: 34-0623) for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf> (JCPDS: 72-1702) for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, and several unidentified products. The TGA curves show a number of overlapping weight losses, indicating the complex decomposition processes. The observed overall weight loss of 51.15% for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>: 42.55%; for 3: 36.29%.) is different from the calculated value of 55.88% for the weight loss of 4 (C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) units and 7.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules (for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>: 50.60% for the loss of 1 (C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) and 0.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O; for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>: 43.11% for the loss of 3 (C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) and 3.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O). The difference between the observed and calculated weight losses can be attributed to the oxidation from P<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> to P<ce:sup loc="post">V</ce:sup> during the decomposition process. The calculated weight gain for the oxidation from P<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> to P<ce:sup loc="post">V</ce:sup> is 6.86% for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 5.86% for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and 7.66% for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. Therefore, the total weight loss would be the observed weight loss plus the calculated weight gain for the oxidation from P<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> to P<ce:sup loc="post">V</ce:sup>: for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 58.01% {(51.15%+6.86%)}; for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, 48.41% {(42.55%+5.86%)}; and for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, 43.95% {(36.29%+7.66%)}. These results are close to the calculated values for the total weight loss of each compound: 55.88% for 1, 50.60% for 2, and 43.11% for 3. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) analysis was performed on powder samples of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> in O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> over a temperature range of 30–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C at a heating rate of 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. For <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the endothermic peak at 118<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C can be interpreted by the loss of the lattice-water molecules. The TGA analysis shows the main weight loss of three compounds in the range of 150–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. So, the DSC peaks at 244 and 269<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; 221<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>; 271<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> can be attributed to the decomposition and loss of amine molecules. From the results of TGA and DSC thermal analysis, the total decomposition process can be written as the following equations: for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>: [(C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O+101/2O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>→3/2 Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>+P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>+;4 NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>+32 CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>+79/2 H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O; for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>: [Zn(C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)(HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)]+25/2 O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>→1/2 Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>+NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>+8CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>+17/2 H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O; and for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>:[(C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)(HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>]+77/2 O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>→2 Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>+1/2 P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>+3 NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>+24 CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>+55/2 H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) using a Perkin Elmer TGA7 thermal analyzer was performed on powder samples of 1, 2, and 3 in O2 over a temperature range of 40-900°C at a heating rate of 10°Cmin-1 (). In the case of 1, a first weight loss of 4.56% occurred in the range of 50-137°C, which corresponds to the loss of the free water molecules (calcd. 4.63%). The X-ray powder patterns of the final decomposition products from the TG analyses showed the presence of Zn2P2O7 (JCPDS: 34-0623) for 1, Zn2P2O7 (JCPDS: 72-1702) for 2 and for 3, and several unidentified products. The TGA curves show a number of overlapping weight losses, indicating the complex decomposition processes. The observed overall weight loss of 51.15% for 1 (for 2: 42.55%; for 3: 36.29%.) is different from the calculated value of 55.88% for the weight loss of 4 (C8H17NH2) units and 7.5H2O molecules (for 2: 50.60% for the loss of 1 (C8H17NH2) and 0.5H2O; for 3: 43.11% for the loss of 3 (C8H17NH2) and 3.5H2O). The difference between the observed and calculated weight losses can be attributed to the oxidation from PIII to PV during the decomposition process. The calculated weight gain for the oxidation from PIII to PV is 6.86% for 1, 5.86% for 2, and 7.66% for 3. Therefore, the total weight loss would be the observed weight loss plus the calculated weight gain for the oxidation from PIII to PV: for 1, 58.01% {(51.15%+6.86%)}; for 2, 48.41% {(42.55%+5.86%)}; and for 3, 43.95% {(36.29%+7.66%)}. These results are close to the calculated values for the total weight loss of each compound: 55.88% for 1, 50.60% for 2, and 43.11% for 3. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) analysis was performed on powder samples of 1, 2, and 3 in O2 over a temperature range of 30-300°C at a heating rate of 5°Cmin-1. For 1, the endothermic peak at 118°C can be interpreted by the loss of the lattice-water molecules. The TGA analysis shows the main weight loss of three compounds in the range of 150-300°C. So, the DSC peaks at 244 and 269°C for 1; 221°C for 2; 271°C for 3 can be attributed to the decomposition and loss of amine molecules. From the results of TGA and DSC thermal analysis, the total decomposition process can be written as the following equations: for 1: [(C8H17NH3)4Zn3(HPO3)5]⋅3H2O+101/2O2→3/2 Zn2P2O7+P2O5+;4 NH3+32 CO2+79/2 H2O; for 2: [Zn(C8H17NH2)(HPO3)]+25/2 O2→1/2 Zn2P2O7+NH3+8CO2+17/2 H2O; and for 3:[(C8H17NH3)2Zn4(C8H17NH2)(HPO3)5]+77/2 O2→2 Zn2P2O7+1/2 P2O5+3 NH3+24 CO2+55/2 H2O.

The spectrum of 1 shows characteristic bands of lattice water molecules at 3550cm-1 (ν  s ) and 1630cm-1 (δ as), which is in agreement with the presence of water molecules in 1 as analyzed from single-crystal X-ray diffraction and thermogravimetric analysis. The other absorption bands with a few variations correspond to the organic amines, and the HPO3 moiety in their respective peaks (). IR (KBr): ν  s (N-H)=3090-3410cm-1, ν(C-H)=2780-2950cm-1, ν  s (P-H)=2360-2390cm-1, ν  s (N-H)=1595-1600cm-1, δ  s (C-H)=1470-1500cm-1, δ  s (C-N)=1360-1400cm-1, ν as(P-O)=1080-1140cm-1, δ as(P-H)=1070-1080cm-1, ν  s (P-O)=999-1026cm-1, δ  s (P-O)=579-596cm-1, δ as(P-O)=455-517cm-1.

<ce:section-title id="sect0040">Single-crystal X-ray diffraction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">Colorless crystals (0.20×0.15×0.10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 0.15×0.15×0.10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and 0.20×0.20×0.15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) were selected for each compound for indexing and intensity data collection on a Bruker X8 Apex2 CCD diffractometer equipped with a normal focus, 3-kW sealed tube X-ray source. Intensity data were collected in 1271 frames with ω scans (width: 0.30° per frame). Empirical absorption corrections based on symmetry equivalents were applied. On the basis of systematic absences and successful solution and refinement of the structures, the space groups were determined to be <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>-1 (No. 2) for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> (No. 14) for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>ca2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> (No. 29) for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. The crystal structures were solved by direct methods followed by difference Fourier syntheses and refined using SHELXTL 5.1 software. The H atoms associated with the P atoms, with the N atoms in the <ce:italic>tert</ce:italic>-octylamine molecules of the three compounds except N(4) in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, and with the water oxygen atoms in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> could be located in the difference maps. Atoms C(22), C(23), C(24), C(27), C(28), C(31), C(32), and N(4) in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and C(8) and C(15) in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are disordered over two sites with equal occupancy. The H atoms bonded to the C atoms in the <ce:italic>tert</ce:italic>-octylamine molecules for the three compounds were positioned geometrically and refined using a riding model with fixed isotropic thermal parameters. The final cycles of least-squares refinement including atomic coordinates and anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms and isotropic thermal parameters of H atoms converged at <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>=0.0551, <ce:italic>wR</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>=0.1612, and <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>=1.05 for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>=0.0398, <ce:italic>wR</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>=0.1028, and <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>=1.00 for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>; and <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>=0.0482, <ce:italic>wR</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>=0.1123, and <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>=1.03 for <ce:bold>3.</ce:bold> All the calculations were performed using the SHELXTL Version 5.1 software package. The crystal data and selected bond lengths are given in <ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0010"></ce:float-anchor>
, respectively. CCDC reference numbers 919156, 919157 and 919158.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Single-crystal X-ray diffraction

Colorless crystals (0.20×0.15×0.10mm3 for 1, 0.15×0.15×0.10mm3 for 2, and 0.20×0.20×0.15mm3 for 3) were selected for each compound for indexing and intensity data collection on a Bruker X8 Apex2 CCD diffractometer equipped with a normal focus, 3-kW sealed tube X-ray source. Intensity data were collected in 1271 frames with ω scans (width: 0.30° per frame). Empirical absorption corrections based on symmetry equivalents were applied. On the basis of systematic absences and successful solution and refinement of the structures, the space groups were determined to be P-1 (No. 2) for 1, P21/c (No. 14) for 2, and Pca21 (No. 29) for 3. The crystal structures were solved by direct methods followed by difference Fourier syntheses and refined using SHELXTL 5.1 software. The H atoms associated with the P atoms, with the N atoms in the tert-octylamine molecules of the three compounds except N(4) in 1, and with the water oxygen atoms in 1 could be located in the difference maps. Atoms C(22), C(23), C(24), C(27), C(28), C(31), C(32), and N(4) in 1 and C(8) and C(15) in 3 are disordered over two sites with equal occupancy. The H atoms bonded to the C atoms in the tert-octylamine molecules for the three compounds were positioned geometrically and refined using a riding model with fixed isotropic thermal parameters. The final cycles of least-squares refinement including atomic coordinates and anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms and isotropic thermal parameters of H atoms converged at R 1=0.0551, wR 2=0.1612, and S=1.05 for 1; R 1=0.0398, wR 2=0.1028, and S=1.00 for 2; and R 1=0.0482, wR 2=0.1123, and S=1.03 for 3. All the calculations were performed using the SHELXTL Version 5.1 software package. The crystal data and selected bond lengths are given in   , respectively. CCDC reference numbers 919156, 919157 and 919158.

<ce:section-title id="sect0045">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sect0050">Description of the structures</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">The three title compounds are interesting examples containing single amines with different roles, as templates in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, as ligands in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and as both templates and ligands in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, and were obtained by adjusting the synthesis conditions. As shown in , the asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains three distinct ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> tetrahedra, five phosphate pseudotetrahedra, four protonated (HTOA)<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cations, and three water molecules. The P(2) and P(5) atoms link to three Zn atoms via oxygen atoms and one hydrogen atom (P–H). All P(1), P(3), and P(4) atoms individually bridge two Zn atoms through oxygen atoms, leaving one terminal P=O group and one P–H bond. Every Zn atom is coordinated by HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> units through oxygen atoms to form a 4-membered ring, which is further linked through the corners to form a layered structure with 20-membered rectangular windows (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>
a). The Zn–O and P–O(P=O) bond distances are in the range from 1.907(3) to 1.959(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and from 1.498(3) to 1.535(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. Each anionic planar sheet is interleaved by protonated template <ce:italic>tert</ce:italic>-octylamine cations and lattice water molecules (b). Several open-framework metal phosphites display extra-large-pore structures (≧18-ring pores) ; however, less layered compounds with large windows are observed. To the best of our knowledge, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is the first known example of a layered metal phosphite that contains a large pore opening of 20-rings.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Description of the structures

The three title compounds are interesting examples containing single amines with different roles, as templates in 1, as ligands in 2, and as both templates and ligands in 3, and were obtained by adjusting the synthesis conditions. As shown in , the asymmetric unit of 1 contains three distinct ZnO4 tetrahedra, five phosphate pseudotetrahedra, four protonated (HTOA)+ cations, and three water molecules. The P(2) and P(5) atoms link to three Zn atoms via oxygen atoms and one hydrogen atom (P-H). All P(1), P(3), and P(4) atoms individually bridge two Zn atoms through oxygen atoms, leaving one terminal P=O group and one P-H bond. Every Zn atom is coordinated by HPO3 units through oxygen atoms to form a 4-membered ring, which is further linked through the corners to form a layered structure with 20-membered rectangular windows ( a). The Zn-O and P-O(P=O) bond distances are in the range from 1.907(3) to 1.959(3)Å and from 1.498(3) to 1.535(3)Å, respectively. Each anionic planar sheet is interleaved by protonated template tert-octylamine cations and lattice water molecules (b). Several open-framework metal phosphites display extra-large-pore structures (≧18-ring pores) ; however, less layered compounds with large windows are observed. To the best of our knowledge, compound 1 is the first known example of a layered metal phosphite that contains a large pore opening of 20-rings.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0070" view="all">In , it can be seen that compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is composed of the following structural units: one ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N tetrahedra, one HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> pseudotetrahedra, and one neutral TOA ligand. The Zn atom is coordinated by three oxygen atoms from three phosphite groups and by one nitrogen atom from one neutral TOA molecule. The P atom bonds to three Zn atoms via oxygen atoms and leaves one P–H group. The Zn–O (or N) and P–O bond distances are in the range from 1.927(3) to 2.032(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and from 1.511(2) to 1.517(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. The ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N and HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> polyhedra connect each other to form a 2D network with a 4.8<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> topology, wherein each 4-ring is enclosed by four 8-rings and each 8-ring is enclosed by four 4-rings (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>
a). The neutral TOA molecules coordinate to Zn atoms and extend away from the layer into the inter-layer region as pendent groups (b). Compound 2 is closely related to several zinc phosphites with 4.8<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> rings ; however, the compounds are different with respect to the layer gaps and the distribution of the tetrahedral groups that point up and down.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In , it can be seen that compound 2 is composed of the following structural units: one ZnO3N tetrahedra, one HPO3 pseudotetrahedra, and one neutral TOA ligand. The Zn atom is coordinated by three oxygen atoms from three phosphite groups and by one nitrogen atom from one neutral TOA molecule. The P atom bonds to three Zn atoms via oxygen atoms and leaves one P-H group. The Zn-O (or N) and P-O bond distances are in the range from 1.927(3) to 2.032(3)Å and from 1.511(2) to 1.517(2)Å, respectively. The ZnO3N and HPO3 polyhedra connect each other to form a 2D network with a 4.82 topology, wherein each 4-ring is enclosed by four 8-rings and each 8-ring is enclosed by four 4-rings ( a). The neutral TOA molecules coordinate to Zn atoms and extend away from the layer into the inter-layer region as pendent groups (b). Compound 2 is closely related to several zinc phosphites with 4.82 rings ; however, the compounds are different with respect to the layer gaps and the distribution of the tetrahedral groups that point up and down.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0075" view="all">The asymmetric unit of compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> contains one ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N tetrahedral, three ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> tetrahedra, one neutral TOA ligand, two protonated (HTOA)<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> template cations, and five HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> pseudotetrahedra (). Zn(1), Zn(2), and Zn(3) are all bridged to four phosphite units through oxygen atoms, whereas Zn(4) is coordinated by three oxygen atoms from three phosphite groups and one nitrogen atom from one neutral TOA ligand. Each P atom bonds to three Zn atoms through oxygen atoms and leaves one P–H group. The Zn–O (or N) and P–O bond distances are in the range from 1.889(4) to 2.049(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and from 1.482(4) to 1.5130(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. The inorganic layer structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is constructed of two parts: a group made of two HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and three ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> tetrahedra, and a tetramer unit built of three HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and one ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N tetrahedra (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>
a and b, respectively). The two parts of the structural units are further connected through their corners to form a [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(TOA)(HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> network with two types of 8-membered rings and one 4-membered ring (c). The organic–inorganic hybrid layer is sandwiched by protonated (HTOA)<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cations (d).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The asymmetric unit of compound 3 contains one ZnO3N tetrahedral, three ZnO4 tetrahedra, one neutral TOA ligand, two protonated (HTOA)+ template cations, and five HPO3 pseudotetrahedra (). Zn(1), Zn(2), and Zn(3) are all bridged to four phosphite units through oxygen atoms, whereas Zn(4) is coordinated by three oxygen atoms from three phosphite groups and one nitrogen atom from one neutral TOA ligand. Each P atom bonds to three Zn atoms through oxygen atoms and leaves one P-H group. The Zn-O (or N) and P-O bond distances are in the range from 1.889(4) to 2.049(4)Å and from 1.482(4) to 1.5130(4)Å, respectively. The inorganic layer structure of 3 is constructed of two parts: a group made of two HPO3 and three ZnO4 tetrahedra, and a tetramer unit built of three HPO3 and one ZnO3N tetrahedra ( a and b, respectively). The two parts of the structural units are further connected through their corners to form a [Zn4(TOA)(HPO3)5]2- network with two types of 8-membered rings and one 4-membered ring (c). The organic-inorganic hybrid layer is sandwiched by protonated (HTOA)+ cations (d).

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0055">Comparison with structures</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">Three zinc phosphites with different structural features in the presence of the same organic amine were produced by adjusting the synthesis conditions. They are all layer structures. The zinc tetrahedra and phosphite pseudotetrahedra connect together to form sheet structures with 20-membered rings for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, with the 4.8<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> topology for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and with two types of 8-membered rings and one 4-membered ring for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, respectively. The <ce:italic>tert</ce:italic>-octylamine molecules as templates in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were sandwiched in between inorganic layers, as ligands in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> coordinated to the Zn of sheets as pendent groups, and acted as both neutral ligands and protonated templates in the structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. Organic amines usually serve as either templates or ligands in metal phosphate/phosphite systems. It is less common that amine molecules play a dual role in one structure. Only two metal phosphates containing diamine molecules  and one metal phosphite containing triamine molecules  have been reported to date. Compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is thus the first example of a metal phosphite in which the monoamine molecules act not only as space-filling counterions but also as monodentate ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Comparison with structures

Three zinc phosphites with different structural features in the presence of the same organic amine were produced by adjusting the synthesis conditions. They are all layer structures. The zinc tetrahedra and phosphite pseudotetrahedra connect together to form sheet structures with 20-membered rings for 1, with the 4.82 topology for 2, and with two types of 8-membered rings and one 4-membered ring for 3, respectively. The tert-octylamine molecules as templates in 1 were sandwiched in between inorganic layers, as ligands in 2 coordinated to the Zn of sheets as pendent groups, and acted as both neutral ligands and protonated templates in the structure of 3. Organic amines usually serve as either templates or ligands in metal phosphate/phosphite systems. It is less common that amine molecules play a dual role in one structure. Only two metal phosphates containing diamine molecules  and one metal phosphite containing triamine molecules  have been reported to date. Compound 3 is thus the first example of a metal phosphite in which the monoamine molecules act not only as space-filling counterions but also as monodentate ligands.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0085" view="all">In summary, we have synthesized three-layered zinc phosphites using hydro(solvo)thermal methods. Adjusting the ratio of Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O/HF/H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>/ tert-octylamine/ethylene glycol/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O led to the formation of interesting compounds containing single amines with different roles; the <ce:italic>tert</ce:italic>-octylamine molecules act as a template in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, as a ligand in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and as both a template and a ligand in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. In the hydro(solvo)thermal synthesis of metal phosphates/phosphites, the highly acidic conditions might cause the amine to be protonated and enable it to act as a charge-balancing template, while a higher pH value during the synthesis might easily lead to the formation of amine metal bonds, in which case the amine acts as a ligand . However, the correlation between the synthesis conditions and the final products is complex, and there are many synthetic variables, such as the choice of solvent, temperature, Zn/P ratio, and pH. In this case, the effect of the pH value was not obvious, and ethylene glycol may be a critical factor influencing the compound structures and the amine coordination state. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has the largest pore opening of 20-rings in known layered metal phosphites, compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is an undulated layer structure with the neutral TOA ligands coordinated to the Zn as pendent groups, and compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> contains amine molecules that act as both templates and ligands which is a very rare example in metal-phosphite system. It is interesting to understand the correlation between the synthesis conditions and the final solid products. Further work on this theme is in progress.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have synthesized three-layered zinc phosphites using hydro(solvo)thermal methods. Adjusting the ratio of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O/HF/H3PO3/ tert-octylamine/ethylene glycol/H2O led to the formation of interesting compounds containing single amines with different roles; the tert-octylamine molecules act as a template in 1, as a ligand in 2, and as both a template and a ligand in 3. In the hydro(solvo)thermal synthesis of metal phosphates/phosphites, the highly acidic conditions might cause the amine to be protonated and enable it to act as a charge-balancing template, while a higher pH value during the synthesis might easily lead to the formation of amine metal bonds, in which case the amine acts as a ligand . However, the correlation between the synthesis conditions and the final products is complex, and there are many synthetic variables, such as the choice of solvent, temperature, Zn/P ratio, and pH. In this case, the effect of the pH value was not obvious, and ethylene glycol may be a critical factor influencing the compound structures and the amine coordination state. Compound 1 has the largest pore opening of 20-rings in known layered metal phosphites, compound 2 is an undulated layer structure with the neutral TOA ligands coordinated to the Zn as pendent groups, and compound 3 contains amine molecules that act as both templates and ligands which is a very rare example in metal-phosphite system. It is interesting to understand the correlation between the synthesis conditions and the final solid products. Further work on this theme is in progress.

cln_elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0030">Experimental section</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sect0035">Synthesis and characterization</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">The hydro(solvo)thermal reactions were carried out in Teflon-lined stainless steel Parr acid digestion bombs at 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>d. Colorless block crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were obtained by heating a mixture of Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), HF(aq) (0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 48% solution), H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M solution), <ce:italic>tert</ce:italic>-octylamine (12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL), and ethylene glycol (4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL). Colorless tablet crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were prepared by heating a mixture of Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), HF(aq) (2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 48% solution), H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M solution), <ce:italic>tert</ce:italic>-octylamine (12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL). Colorless tablet crystals of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were synthesized by heating a mixture of Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), HF(aq) (2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 48% solution), H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M solution), <ce:italic>tert</ce:italic>-octylamine (12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (1.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL), and ethylene glycol (5.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL). The addition of ethylene glycol (1–2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) to the same reaction condition of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> led the formation of the mixture of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. Attempts to synthesize <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> without ethylene glycol were unsuccessful.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental section

Synthesis and characterization

The hydro(solvo)thermal reactions were carried out in Teflon-lined stainless steel Parr acid digestion bombs at 120°C for 3d. Colorless block crystals of 1 were obtained by heating a mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.5mmol), HF(aq) (0.5mmol, 48% solution), H3PO3 (7mmol, 8M solution), tert-octylamine (12mmol), H2O (1mL), and ethylene glycol (4mL). Colorless tablet crystals of 2 were prepared by heating a mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.5mmol), HF(aq) (2mmol, 48% solution), H3PO3 (3mmol, 8M solution), tert-octylamine (12mmol), and H2O (5mL). Colorless tablet crystals of 3 were synthesized by heating a mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.4mmol), HF(aq) (2mmol, 48% solution), H3PO3 (6mmol, 8M solution), tert-octylamine (12mmol), H2O (1.4mL), and ethylene glycol (5.6mL). The addition of ethylene glycol (1-2mL) to the same reaction condition of 2 led the formation of the mixture of 1 and 2. Attempts to synthesize 1 and 3 without ethylene glycol were unsuccessful.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) using a Perkin Elmer TGA7 thermal analyzer was performed on powder samples of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> in O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> over a temperature range of 40–900<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C at a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (). In the case of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, a first weight loss of 4.56% occurred in the range of 50–137<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, which corresponds to the loss of the free water molecules (calcd. 4.63%). The X-ray powder patterns of the final decomposition products from the TG analyses showed the presence of Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf> (JCPDS: 34-0623) for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf> (JCPDS: 72-1702) for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, and several unidentified products. The TGA curves show a number of overlapping weight losses, indicating the complex decomposition processes. The observed overall weight loss of 51.15% for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>: 42.55%; for 3: 36.29%.) is different from the calculated value of 55.88% for the weight loss of 4 (C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) units and 7.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules (for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>: 50.60% for the loss of 1 (C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) and 0.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O; for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>: 43.11% for the loss of 3 (C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) and 3.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O). The difference between the observed and calculated weight losses can be attributed to the oxidation from P<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> to P<ce:sup loc="post">V</ce:sup> during the decomposition process. The calculated weight gain for the oxidation from P<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> to P<ce:sup loc="post">V</ce:sup> is 6.86% for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 5.86% for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and 7.66% for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. Therefore, the total weight loss would be the observed weight loss plus the calculated weight gain for the oxidation from P<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> to P<ce:sup loc="post">V</ce:sup>: for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 58.01% {(51.15%+6.86%)}; for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, 48.41% {(42.55%+5.86%)}; and for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, 43.95% {(36.29%+7.66%)}. These results are close to the calculated values for the total weight loss of each compound: 55.88% for 1, 50.60% for 2, and 43.11% for 3. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) analysis was performed on powder samples of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> in O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> over a temperature range of 30–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C at a heating rate of 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. For <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the endothermic peak at 118<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C can be interpreted by the loss of the lattice-water molecules. The TGA analysis shows the main weight loss of three compounds in the range of 150–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. So, the DSC peaks at 244 and 269<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; 221<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>; 271<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> can be attributed to the decomposition and loss of amine molecules. From the results of TGA and DSC thermal analysis, the total decomposition process can be written as the following equations: for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>: [(C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O+101/2O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>→3/2 Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>+P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>+;4 NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>+32 CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>+79/2 H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O; for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>: [Zn(C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)(HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)]+25/2 O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>→1/2 Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>+NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>+8CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>+17/2 H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O; and for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>:[(C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)(HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>]+77/2 O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>→2 Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>+1/2 P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>+3 NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>+24 CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>+55/2 H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="sect0040">Single-crystal X-ray diffraction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">Colorless crystals (0.20×0.15×0.10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 0.15×0.15×0.10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and 0.20×0.20×0.15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) were selected for each compound for indexing and intensity data collection on a Bruker X8 Apex2 CCD diffractometer equipped with a normal focus, 3-kW sealed tube X-ray source. Intensity data were collected in 1271 frames with ω scans (width: 0.30° per frame). Empirical absorption corrections based on symmetry equivalents were applied. On the basis of systematic absences and successful solution and refinement of the structures, the space groups were determined to be <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>-1 (No. 2) for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> (No. 14) for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>ca2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> (No. 29) for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. The crystal structures were solved by direct methods followed by difference Fourier syntheses and refined using SHELXTL 5.1 software. The H atoms associated with the P atoms, with the N atoms in the <ce:italic>tert</ce:italic>-octylamine molecules of the three compounds except N(4) in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, and with the water oxygen atoms in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> could be located in the difference maps. Atoms C(22), C(23), C(24), C(27), C(28), C(31), C(32), and N(4) in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and C(8) and C(15) in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are disordered over two sites with equal occupancy. The H atoms bonded to the C atoms in the <ce:italic>tert</ce:italic>-octylamine molecules for the three compounds were positioned geometrically and refined using a riding model with fixed isotropic thermal parameters. The final cycles of least-squares refinement including atomic coordinates and anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms and isotropic thermal parameters of H atoms converged at <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>

cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) using a Perkin Elmer TGA7 thermal analyzer was performed on powder samples of 1, 2, and 3 in O2 over a temperature range of 40-900°C at a heating rate of 10°Cmin-1 (). In the case of 1, a first weight loss of 4.56% occurred in the range of 50-137°C, which corresponds to the loss of the free water molecules (calcd. 4.63%). The X-ray powder patterns of the final decomposition products from the TG analyses showed the presence of Zn2P2O7 (JCPDS: 34-0623) for 1, Zn2P2O7 (JCPDS: 72-1702) for 2 and for 3, and several unidentified products. The TGA curves show a number of overlapping weight losses, indicating the complex decomposition processes. The observed overall weight loss of 51.15% for 1 (for 2: 42.55%; for 3: 36.29%.) is different from the calculated value of 55.88% for the weight loss of 4 (C8H17NH2) units and 7.5H2O molecules (for 2: 50.60% for the loss of 1 (C8H17NH2) and 0.5H2O; for 3: 43.11% for the loss of 3 (C8H17NH2) and 3.5H2O). The difference between the observed and calculated weight losses can be attributed to the oxidation from PIII to PV during the decomposition process. The calculated weight gain for the oxidation from PIII to PV is 6.86% for 1, 5.86% for 2, and 7.66% for 3. Therefore, the total weight loss would be the observed weight loss plus the calculated weight gain for the oxidation from PIII to PV: for 1, 58.01% {(51.15%+6.86%)}; for 2, 48.41% {(42.55%+5.86%)}; and for 3, 43.95% {(36.29%+7.66%)}. These results are close to the calculated values for the total weight loss of each compound: 55.88% for 1, 50.60% for 2, and 43.11% for 3. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) analysis was performed on powder samples of 1, 2, and 3 in O2 over a temperature range of 30-300°C at a heating rate of 5°Cmin-1. For 1, the endothermic peak at 118°C can be interpreted by the loss of the lattice-water molecules. The TGA analysis shows the main weight loss of three compounds in the range of 150-300°C. So, the DSC peaks at 244 and 269°C for 1; 221°C for 2; 271°C for 3 can be attributed to the decomposition and loss of amine molecules. From the results of TGA and DSC thermal analysis, the total decomposition process can be written as the following equations: for 1: [(C8H17NH3)4Zn3(HPO3)5]⋅3H2O+101/2O2→3/2 Zn2P2O7+P2O5+;4 NH3+32 CO2+79/2 H2O; for 2: [Zn(C8H17NH2)(HPO3)]+25/2 O2→1/2 Zn2P2O7+NH3+8CO2+17/2 H2O; and for 3:[(C8H17NH3)2Zn4(C8H17NH2)(HPO3)5]+77/2 O2→2 Zn2P2O7+1/2 P2O5+3 NH3+24 CO2+55/2 H2O.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction

Colorless crystals (0.20×0.15×0.10mm3 for 1, 0.15×0.15×0.10mm3 for 2, and 0.20×0.20×0.15mm3 for 3) were selected for each compound for indexing and intensity data collection on a Bruker X8 Apex2 CCD diffractometer equipped with a normal focus, 3-kW sealed tube X-ray source. Intensity data were collected in 1271 frames with ω scans (width: 0.30° per frame). Empirical absorption corrections based on symmetry equivalents were applied. On the basis of systematic absences and successful solution and refinement of the structures, the space groups were determined to be P-1 (No. 2) for 1, P21/c (No. 14) for 2, and Pca21 (No. 29) for 3. The crystal structures were solved by direct methods followed by difference Fourier syntheses and refined using SHELXTL 5.1 software. The H atoms associated with the P atoms, with the N atoms in the tert-octylamine molecules of the three compounds except N(4) in 1, and with the water oxygen atoms in 1 could be located in the difference maps. Atoms C(22), C(23), C(24), C(27), C(28), C(31), C(32), and N(4) in 1 and C(8) and C(15) in 3 are disordered over two sites with equal occupancy. The H atoms bonded to the C atoms in the tert-octylamine molecules for the three compounds were positioned geometrically and refined using a riding model with fixed isotropic thermal parameters. The final cycles of least-squares refinement including atomic coordinates and anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms and isotropic thermal parameters of H atoms converged at R 1=0.0551, wR 2=0.1612, and S=1.05 for 1; R 1=0.0398, wR 2=0.1028, and S=1.00 for 2; and R 1=0.0482, wR 2=0.1123, and S=1.03 for 3. All the calculations were performed using the SHELXTL Version 5.1 software package. The crystal data and selected bond lengths are given in   , respectively. CCDC reference numbers 919156, 919157 and 919158.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cap0005">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">(a) Section of an inorganic layer with 20-ring windows in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> viewed along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis. (b) Arrangement of the layers in the <ce:italic>bc</ce:italic> plane. The yellow and green polyhedra represent ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, respectively. The blue, black, and red circles indicate the N atoms, C atoms, and water molecules, respectively. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  (a) Section of an inorganic layer with 20-ring windows in 1 viewed along the c axis. (b) Arrangement of the layers in the bc plane. The yellow and green polyhedra represent ZnO4 and HPO3, respectively. The blue, black, and red circles indicate the N atoms, C atoms, and water molecules, respectively. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

cln_elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0010">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cap0010">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">(a) View of the neutral layer in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> formed by 4- and 8-membered rings. (b) Arrangement of the layers in the <ce:italic>ab</ce:italic> plane. The yellow and green polyhedra represent ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N and HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, respectively. The blue and black circles indicate the N and C atoms, respectively. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  (a) View of the neutral layer in 2 formed by 4- and 8-membered rings. (b) Arrangement of the layers in the ab plane. The yellow and green polyhedra represent ZnO3N and HPO3, respectively. The blue and black circles indicate the N and C atoms, respectively. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

cln_elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0015">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cap0015">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">Two different types of structural units in <ce:bold>3:</ce:bold> (a) a group formed by three ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and two HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> tetrahedra, and (b) a unit formed by one ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N and three HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> tetrahedra. (c) A section of the inorganic layer showing two types of 8-membered rings and one 4-membered ring. (d) Arrangement of the layers in the <ce:italic>ab</ce:italic> plane. The orange, yellow, and green polyhedra represent ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N, ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, and HPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, respectively. The blue and black circles indicate the N and C atoms, respectively. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr3"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  Two different types of structural units in 3: (a) a group formed by three ZnO4 and two HPO3 tetrahedra, and (b) a unit formed by one ZnO3N and three HPO3 tetrahedra. (c) A section of the inorganic layer showing two types of 8-membered rings and one 4-membered ring. (d) Arrangement of the layers in the ab plane. The orange, yellow, and green polyhedra represent ZnO3N, ZnO4, and HPO3, respectively. The blue and black circles indicate the N and C atoms, respectively. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)
